act:act.act:title: Enforcement of Canadian Judgments and Decrees Act

bcl:text.#text:
means an order for tariff costs, or an order for monetary
            penalties, made by a presiding body;

means a judgment, decree or order made in a civil
            proceeding by a court of a province or territory of Canada other than British
            Columbia

bcl:text:
and, subject to section 1.1, includes a domestic trade agreement
            award, but does not include a judgment, decree or order that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that requires a person to pay money, including

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text:
an order for the payment of money that is made in the exercise of a judicial
                function by a tribunal of a province or territory of Canada other than British
                Columbia and that is enforceable as a judgment of the superior court of unlimited
                trial jurisdiction in that province or territory, and

bcl:text.#text:
an order made and entered under section 741 of the  in a court of a province or territory
                of Canada other than British Columbia,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
under which a person is required to do or not do an act or thing,
              or

that declares rights, obligations or status in relation to a person or
              thing,

bcl:text.#text:
is for maintenance or support, including an order enforceable under the
                ,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
is for the payment of money as a penalty or fine for committing an
              offence,

relates to the care, control or welfare of a minor, except in the case of a
              Canadian civil protection order,

is made by a tribunal of a province or territory of Canada other than British
              Columbia, whether or not it is enforceable as an order of the superior court of
              unlimited trial jurisdiction of that province or territory, to
              the extent that it provides for relief other than the payment of money, or

relates to the granting of probate or issuing a grant of administration or the
              administration of the estate of a deceased person;

bcl:text.#text: means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the AIT,
the NWPTA,
the TILMA, or
a prescribed trade agreement;

bcl:text.#text: means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an AIT award,
a NWPTA award,
a TILMA award, or
a prescribed award under a prescribed trade agreement;

bcl:text.#text:
includes requiring that a Canadian judgment be recognized
            by any person or authority, whether or not further relief is sought;
means,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a Canadian judgment that is not a domestic trade agreement award, a person entitled to enforce the Canadian judgment in the province or territory of Canada where the Canadian judgment was made, or
in the case of a Canadian judgment that is a domestic trade agreement award, a person in whose favour the Canadian judgment was made;

bcl:text.#text: means

bcl:text: and includes an award of costs under Article 32 (1) of the NWPTA;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
a monetary award within the meaning of Article 29 (7) of the NWPTA if no
              judicial review has been requested in relation to that award under Article 31 (1) of
              the NWPTA within the 15 day period referred to in that Article,

a monetary award within the meaning of Article 29 (7) of the NWPTA
              if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text:
a judicial review has been requested in relation to that award under Article
                31 (1) of the NWPTA within the 15 day period referred to in that Article,
                and

the judicial review court determines that the award should neither be set
                aside nor remitted to a NWPTA panel, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
if a judicial review of a monetary award within the meaning of Article 29 (7)
              of the NWPTA has been requested under Article 31 (1) of the NWPTA and the judicial
              review court remits the award to a NWPTA panel, the monetary award as confirmed or
              amended by that NWPTA panel,

bcl:text.#text:
means a panel convened under Article 26 or 29 of the
            NWPTA;
means an agreement into which the government of British Columbia or the government of Canada has entered that is prescribed as a prescribed trade agreement;

has the same meaning as Presiding Body in the
            AIT;
does not include the Northwest Territories, Yukon or Nunavut;

means a Canadian judgment that is
            registered under this Act;
means

bcl:text: and includes an award of costs under Article 32 (1) of the TILMA;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
a monetary award within the meaning of Article 29 (7) of the TILMA if no
              judicial review has been requested in relation to that award under Article 31 (1) of
              the TILMA within the 15 day period referred to in that Article,

a monetary award within the meaning of Article 29 (7) of the TILMA
              if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text:
judicial review has been requested in relation to that award under Article
                31 (1) of the TILMA within the 15 day period referred to in that Article, and

the judicial review court determines that the award should neither be set
                aside nor remitted to a TILMA panel, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
if judicial review has been requested under Article 31 (1) of the TILMA of a
              monetary award within the meaning of Article 29 (7) of the TILMA and the judicial
              review court remits the award to a TILMA panel, the monetary award as confirmed or
              amended by that TILMA panel,

bcl:text.#text:
means a panel convened under Article 26 or 29 of the
            TILMA.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: When used in relation to a domestic trade agreement award,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a reference in section 3 (1) (a) to a judge, registrar, clerk or other proper officer of the court that made the Canadian judgment is deemed to be,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text:
in the case of an AIT award, a reference to a member of the presiding body
              that made the AIT award,

in the case of a NWPTA award, a reference to a member of the NWPTA panel that
              made the NWPTA award,

in the case of a TILMA award, a reference to a member of the TILMA panel that
              made the TILMA award, or

in the case of an award referred to in paragraph (d) of the definition of "domestic trade agreement award" in subsection (1), a reference to the person, or to a member of the panel or other body, that made the award,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: [Repealed 2012-11-4.]

a reference in sections 6 (1) and (3) (a) and (c) and 10 (a) and (b) to a
            proceeding is deemed to be a reference to the proceedings that led to the domestic trade
            agreement award, and
a reference in section 6 (3) (a) and (b) to the judge, court or tribunal that made the Canadian judgment is deemed to be,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in the case of an AIT award, a reference to the presiding body that made the AIT award,
in the case of a NWPTA award, a reference to the NWPTA panel that made the NWPTA award,
in the case of a TILMA award, a reference to the TILMA panel that made the TILMA award, or

in the case of an award referred to in paragraph (d) of the definition of "domestic trade agreement award" in subsection (1) of this section, a reference to the person, panel or other body that made the award.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If a Canadian judgment or a registered Canadian judgment is a domestic trade
          agreement award,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
sections 6 (2)
            (c) (ii) to (iv) and 9 do not apply, and

a reference in section 4 to sections 5 and 6 is deemed
            to be a reference to sections 5 and 6 (1), (2) (a),
              (b) 
           and (c) (i) and (v),  (3) and (4).

bcl:text.#text:
If a registered Canadian judgment is a domestic trade agreement award against the
          government, the following must accord with the :

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
enforcement of that registered Canadian judgment under section 4 of
            this Act;

an order in respect of that registered Canadian judgment under section 6 (2)
            (a), (b) or (c) (i) or (v) of this Act.

bcl:text:
Subject to subsection (2), nothing in subsection (1) affects the power of
          the Supreme Court to make, in relation to a registered Canadian judgment that is a
          domestic trade agreement award, any order in relation to the enforcement of that
          registered Canadian judgment, including, without limitation, any order

that the court may make in relation to the enforcement of any other order or
          judgment of the court.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
staying or limiting the enforcement of that registered Canadian judgment,
            or

respecting the procedure to be used for the enforcement of that registered
            Canadian judgment,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Subject to subsection (2), a Canadian judgment, whether or not the Canadian judgment is final,
          may be registered under this Act for the purpose of enforcement.

A Canadian judgment that requires a person to pay money may not be registered
          under this Act for the purpose of enforcement unless it is a final judgment.

A Canadian judgment that also contains provisions for relief that may not be
          enforced under this Act may be registered under this Act except in respect of those
          provisions.

A Canadian judgment is registered under this Act by paying the fee prescribed by
          regulation and by filing in the registry of the Supreme Court

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
a copy of the Canadian judgment, certified as true by a judge, registrar, clerk or other
            proper officer of the court that made the Canadian judgment, and

the additional information or material required by the applicable Rules of
            Court.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Subject to sections 5 and 6, a registered Canadian judgment,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
subject to paragraph (b), may be enforced in British Columbia as if it were an order or
          judgment of, and entered in, the Supreme Court, or

in the case of a registered Canadian judgment that is a domestic trade agreement
          award, may be enforced in British Columbia as if it were an order or judgment of, and
          entered in, the Supreme Court, but only if and to the extent that that enforcement or
          entry is not restricted by the applicable domestic trade agreement.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Time limit for registration and enforcement

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A Canadian judgment, other than a Canadian judgment that is a domestic trade agreement award, that requires a person to pay money must not be registered or
          enforced under this Act

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
after the time for enforcement has expired in the province or territory of Canada where
            the Canadian judgment was made, or

later than 10 years after the date on which the Canadian judgment became enforceable in
            the province or territory of Canada where it was made.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A Canadian judgment that is a domestic trade agreement award must not be registered or enforced under this Act more than 10 years after the date on which the Canadian judgment was made.

Equitable doctrines and rules of law in relation to delay apply to the enforcement
          of a Canadian judgment, to the extent that it provides for relief other than the payment
          of money.

A party to the proceeding in which a registered Canadian judgment was made may
          apply to the Supreme Court for directions respecting its enforcement.
On an application under subsection (1), the court may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
make an order that the Canadian judgment be modified as may be required to make it
            enforceable in conformity with local practice,

make an order stipulating the procedure to be used in enforcing the Canadian judgment,
            or

make an order staying or limiting the enforcement of the Canadian judgment, subject to
            any terms and for any period the court considers appropriate in the circumstances,
            if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text:
such an order could be made in respect of an order or judgment of the Supreme
              Court under the applicable Rules of Court or any enactment relating to legal remedies
              and the enforcement of orders and judgments,

the party against whom enforcement is sought has brought, or intends to bring,
              in the province or territory of Canada where the Canadian judgment was made, a proceeding to set
              aside, vary or obtain other relief in respect of the Canadian judgment,

an order staying or limiting enforcement is in effect in the province or
              territory of Canada where the Canadian judgment was made,
the Canadian judgment is contrary to public policy in British Columbia, or

the Canadian judgment is a domestic trade agreement award and the ability to enforce that domestic trade agreement award is, under the terms of the domestic trade agreement, suspended or otherwise ineffective.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Notwithstanding subsection (2), the Supreme Court must not make an order
          staying or limiting the enforcement of a registered Canadian judgment solely on the
          grounds that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
the judge, court or tribunal that made the Canadian judgment lacked jurisdiction over the
            subject matter of the proceeding that led to the Canadian judgment, or over the party against
            whom enforcement is sought, under

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: principles of private international law, or

the domestic law of the province or territory of Canada where the Canadian judgment was
              made,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
the Supreme Court would have come to a different decision on a finding of fact
            or law or on an exercise of discretion from the decision of the judge, court or tribunal
            that made the Canadian judgment, or
a defect existed in the process or proceeding leading to the Canadian judgment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
An application for directions must be made under subsection (1) before any measures
          are taken to enforce a registered Canadian judgment if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
the enforceability of the Canadian judgment is, by its terms, subject to the satisfaction
            of a condition, or
the Canadian judgment was obtained without notice to the persons bound by it.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
To the extent that a registered Canadian judgment requires a person to pay money,
          interest is payable as if it were an order or judgment of the Supreme Court.

For the purpose of calculating interest payable under subsection (1),
          the amount owing on the registered Canadian judgment is the total of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
the amount owing on the Canadian judgment on the date it is registered under this Act,
            and
interest that has accrued to that date under,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in the case of a Canadian judgment that is not a domestic trade agreement award, the laws applicable to the calculation of interest on the Canadian judgment in the province or territory of Canada where it was made, or
in the case of a Canadian judgment that is a domestic trade agreement award, the laws of British Columbia.

bcl:section.bcl:text:
An enforcing party is entitled to recover all costs, charges and
        disbursements

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
reasonably incurred in the registration of a Canadian judgment under this Act,
          and
assessed or allowed by a registrar of the Supreme Court.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote:
Enforcing parties' other rights not affected by
        registration
bcl:section.bcl:text:
Neither registering a Canadian judgment nor taking other proceedings under this Act
        affects an enforcing party's right to bring an action on the Canadian judgment or on the
        original cause of action.

bcl:text.#text:
A Canadian civil protection order is deemed, without registration under this Act,
          to be an order made under Part 9 of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Nothing in subsection (1) prevents a person from registering a
          Canadian civil protection order under this Act.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
a Canadian judgment made in a proceeding commenced after this Act comes into
          force, and

a Canadian judgment made in a proceeding commenced before this Act comes into
          force and in which the party against whom enforcement is sought took part.

bcl:text.#text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations referred to in section 41 of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting any matter for which regulations are contemplated by this Act.

bcl:section.bcl:text:
This Act comes into force by regulation of the Lieutenant Governor in
        Council.

bcl:editorialnote.in:em: [Note: See Table of Legislative Changes for the status of sections 11 to 18.]
